Author: gabor_papp

Content:
That came out really nice, congratulations.

I'm curious about what made you guys go ahead with the project after the initial intimidation with the shape of the building.

You inspired me to give GWEN a try, it's pretty sweet.  A bit of work to get up and running in cinder, though (I've got it rendering with his OpenGL renderer, just started writing a cinder-based renderer for fonts/textures).  How did you go about this?  Any plans to share that work?
Author: reakinator

Content:
Hi Folks,

I'd like to share with you one of the last project I've been working on. Even if I've been using Cinder for several years now, I think I never posted here in the gallery! Cinder was used as our main tool in production for the first time here in a quite big project, so I thought it was important to say one more time how much Cinder rules!

http://www.antivj.com/paleodictyon/

I originally wanted to make a long post here, but this post ended being way to long and way to illustrated to be on a forum so you can read about the process and the software development here: 

http://blog.antivj.com/2013/bacteria-farming-and-software-design/

I ported a small part of the original software to WebGl if you want to have a look: http://www.antivj.com/paleodictyon_app (you'll need a good computer, chrome and good bandwidth)

Thanks again to Andrew, all the team and the amazingly helpful people around here!
Author: simongeilfus

Content:
Congratulations, Simon! The project looks great and I enjoyed reading through the process post.

I'm especially intrigued by the CV component for bringing in content drawn through other means.
Author: sansumbrella

Content:
Beautiful, and greatly documented (sympa de te voir en vrai...)

I wish I could have seen this in real in Metz.

The WebGL app is interesting too. Are you projecting a video over the geometry?
I wonder how you managed to achieve AA in OSX chrome btw.

But maybe the most fascinating part is to see you interacting with the fabulous tools you created during the making of this work!..

So thumbs up to antivj (I knew Joanie Lemercier's work beforehand, now you're on the map too as far as I'm concerned...)

A+
Author: ariel.malka

Content:
Hey! Thank you all so much, I'm glad you liked it, it is always difficult to make proper documentation for that kind of project...

@sansumbrela: You'll be disappointed by how simple those modules were. I used contours detection for most "objects" and a good old getPixel for the others. No fancy CV functions here, would have make sense with the particles to try optical flow but didn't had time for that ... And well also it worked for me because most video footages were highly contrasted (read black and white polygons).

@ariel: (hehe, oui c'est bien moi, apr√®s 3-4 nuits blanches!) About the WebGL app, you're right, the funny thing is that I'm actually exactly doing what we do for the actual installation... using virtual projectors / cameras to project a video on the geometry. All the code is there if you are interested (it was ported from cinder)! About the AA, google disabled it two days after I started the project, so I'm using a combination of fxaa and a higher resolution render target. A bit expensive (especially the double resolution) but it works pretty well.

@rain2012: here you go: https://github.com/garrynewman/GWEN (but don't expect finding a timeline or a nodegraph there!)

Thanks again! :)
Author: simongeilfus

Content: I echo everyone here. It's wonderful! And many thanks for the write up!
Author: djmichaelalex

Content:
Hey thanks!
I'm curious about what made you guys go ahead with the project after the initial intimidation with the shape of the building. 
Good question, not sure when exactly we changed our mind about that! I think the fact that we could chose the service provider / technical team we were going to work with, gave us much more confidence. Our friends Lumens 8 worked with us for the technical (broadcasting?) side of the project, and their expertise definitely made the difference!
You inspired me to give GWEN a try, it's pretty sweet.
Yep, Gwen is quite nice. I had to hack it quite a lot to make those widgets possible, so I'm not sure I'm going to continue building on top of it... But I was actually thinking about cleaning what I already have and upload that to github ... ( In the meantime I can send you a zip with the Cinder Renderer )
